Oh, I don't know much about anyting!
You should ask Mr. O'Brien here - he does joined-up writing.
Would you be one o' dem history fellas yourself?
That's right! Professor Stobbart, Miskatonic University.
You're an archaeologist? And you're asking us about the castle?
Excuse me, Mister O'Brien! D' gentleman was talkin' t' me!
I thought you said you were a reporter?
Yeah, I am, but I studied to be an archaeologist.
Oh, no - I'm an archaeologist.
I'm researching the story of Lochmarne Castle for a scientific journal.
Oh, I see!
How come you didn't leave with d' others?
I didn't know they'd gone until the landlord told me.
I didn't know they'd gone!
Oh, yes. Packed dere spades and shovels and away dey went.
Seems I missed all the excitement!
What excitement?
Professor Peagram's discovery!
Haven't you heard?
No?
Oh, no. I'm here on vacation.
What's dat?
A vacation, Pat. It's what the Americans call a holiday.
But he's lying to you, anyhow. He told me he's a journalist.
Oh. What's wrong wid dat?
Journalists are mostly scum, Pat.
What? Even Clark Kent? I can't believe it!
Oh, right. In Lochmarne? You come to Lochmarne for a holiday?
Sure. It's a very pretty place.
Where d' hell are you from, mister?
California.
Ha-ha. Yeah... amongst other things.
No, I don't.
I mean, I know who he is, but I don't know him to talk to.
Where has Peagram gone?
He's disappeared! Gone! Skedaddled!
And... nobody knows where he's gone!
Except you...?
No, I don't know either.
Do you know anything about Peagram's excavation?
Only dat he didn't have d' right tools for d' job.
What he needed was shovels and a J.C.B.!
Peagram was digging for historical remains, not coal.
Is dat a fact? What d' hell for?
It's the science of archaeology, Pat.
Understanding how people used to live by what they've left behind.
One day archaeologists might be digging up OUR remains.
Imagine dat, Mister O'Brien! I wonder what dey'll find?
Well, it won't be arrow-heads and beakers.
Fast food cartons and flavored condoms, more likely.
Did anyone from the village work at Peagram's dig?
I tried it meself, but dat high-an'-mighty history man called me incontinent!
What a nerve! Hadn't I dug more holes dan d' rest o' dem put togedder?
Do you remember seeing Sean Fitzgerald at the dig?
Hmm... Let me see, now...
I tink me brainbox needs a spot o'lubrication.
Do you remember Sean Fitzgerald now?
I can picture d' scene as if it was only last week.
Come to think of it, it WAS only last week.
Fitzgerald was dere all right, him an' a bunch o' students.
He was speakin' wid the boss man.
Aren't you going to help Fitzgerald?
What does he need my help for?
Didn't you hear what Maguire said? He's been hit by a car!
What an idiot! People call me stupid, but I've never done that.
Don't you feel any sympathy for poor Fitzgerald?
He never bothered about me, so why should I?
Is it true that Peagram found a valuable gem?
What? First I heard of it!
Take no notice of that fella, Pat. He's a journalist.
Where have you been, Pat?
That gem is the talk of every town from Lochmarne to Ballydoon.
Nobody told me! The lucky sod! So that's why he's scampered...
Do you know anything about the Knights Templar?
And who might dey be?
A bunch of guys from way back in the times of the Crusades.
Ah, history never was me best subject.
Father Mahoney never taught you history!
You were thrown out for disrupting the class.
I know, I know! But if he had it wouldn'a bin me best subject.
How can you learn about sometin' that happened when you wasn't dere?
I never heard o'their likes before you brought them up.
Have you heard o' these knights, Mister O'Brien?
Ah, sure - I read about them in the Reader's Digest.
A fascinating article on their revolutionary financial methods.
Christ! History's not what it used to be.
What do you know about leprechauns, Doyle?
Leprechauns! Is it d' liddle people you're talkin' about?
Sure and a cousin o' mine was wed to one.
Oh, come on! Do you really expect me to believe that?
It's d' truth I'm tellin' you. She fell asleep on a fairy ring, see?
When she woke up there he was, a liddle fella, all in green!
Tell me more about your cousin and the leprechaun...
Oh, no...
Well, young Mary was speechless - especially when the leprechaun up and spoke to her!
Be my bride me darlin' says he, an' you'll never want for riches again.
Okay, says she, an' he slips a ring o' daisies on her finger.
Amen.
So there y'are - proof that d' liddle people exist!
That's no proof! All you have is her word for it!
Not so - the followin' spring she had a liddle baby!
Did the leprechaun's promise come true?
What promise was that, now?
That she'd never want for riches again.
Now there's the strangest thing. She never did!
I thought you said she was claiming the social, Pat?
Indeed, Mister O'Brien, but there's riches and riches...
She told me - Pat, she says, that liddle darlin' boy is all the riches in d' world t' me!
Oh, nothing really.
'Bye for now...
What do you think of this towel?
Now there's a fine piece of cloth if ever I did see one!
I found it on the bar, under your elbow.
I thought it looked familiar.
Look at this towel...
You showed me that before.
What does this false nose mean to you?
Ah, now - you're a clown.
No, not me...
Ah! You're a good one, aren't ya?
Did you hear that, Michael?
I hate clowns.
Ha! Listen to this fella! I hate clowns, says he.
Isn't he just the funniest man you ever did see, Michael?
He's not a clown, Doyle.
He's not even remotely funny.
Thanks.
Have you seen this nose before?
Yes, mister.
Before I showed it to you the first time, I mean.
Uh... when was that?
Never mind.
No, sir. Definitely not.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
It's a handsome mug on that fella, to be sure. Is he a film star?
Don't be fooled - this is the face of a psychopathic killer!
No! Well, there's one in the eye for me and my mouth!
Are you sure you haven't seen this man?
It's the face of a therapeutic killer.
Oh, never mind...
Does this piece of wire mean anything to you?
Not me, mister.
Do you recognize this gem?
Saints be praised! It must be worth a fortune!
Maybe it is. Have you seen it before?
It's the one which Peagram took from the dig.
Oh. How come you've got it now?
He left it behind. I'm looking after it.
Oh. You could take that to Dublin an' sell it.
Yes - you showed me before.
Does this security pass mean anything to you?
Uh... hmmm. Well... no.
What do you make of this tool?
It's for lifting manhole covers.
That's right! I, uh... found it in Paris.
Will you look at that! A French sewer key. Marvellous!
Do you recognize this matchbook?
No.
Do you recognise this white powder?
No, I don't.
May I shake your hand...?
No, you can't.
How come?
Because I'll spill my beer if you do.
Does this tissue mean anything to you?
No, but you should show that to my granny.
She could tell your fortune from it.
From a soiled tissue?
Sure! Some people read tea-leaves - my granny reads handkerchiefs.
No, boss.
What do you think of this flashlight?
It's not very bright, is it?
I could say the same about some of the present company...
That's true. But don't let him hear you.
Keep it under your hat, mister.
That flashlight, like your brain Doyle, is not switched on.
I don't think he heard me.
You showed me before, mister.
Hello!
He was engrossed in conversation with the other men...
Ah, hello there. Let me introduce you to my pals...
We've already met.
What now?
I want you to know you have my sympathy...
Oh, it's just terrible! Awful!
It's the worst news I heard all day.
It's topped the bad news all right, for this week and the next.
The whole year...
It's worse than that - it's the worst disaster in living memory!
Isn't it the biggest calamity in the history of the village?
I would say it's the biggest in the history of Ireland!
The most awesome disaster since mankind paddled out of the primal plop...
There's no beer.
I dare say I'll get over it...
What about Sean? Why aren't you out looking for him?
There's no point in launching an ill-equipped expedition to save the lad.
In a life or death situation, preparation is essential.
That's why I slipped in here.
For a pint.
Is a glass of beer more important than a man's life!?
Were you talking to me?
To all of you! Sean Fitzgerald has met with god-knows-what, and all you can do is drink!
Sean has gone for a ride in a flash car, that's all.
Why don't you calm down and join us?
I gotta go...
Do you know anything about this piece of wire?
It looks like a hand made snare.
Do you have any use for this towel?
I suppose I could squeeze it out into my glass if I was desperate enough...
Does this false nose mean anything to you?
You're a circus clown.
No, but I got this from someone who disguised himself as a clown.
Is that a fact? Why did he do that now?
He's a psychotic killer. I think he may be connected with Peagram's disappearance.
Do I show you this nose?
Yes, you did.
Do you recognise the name on this card?
I can't read that little writing!
Is that your name? Tommy Merlin?
No...
But what a great stage name! It had what my high-school hypnosis act had lacked: style and class!
For a few seconds I bathed in spot lights on a thundering tide of applause: Tommy Merlin, Hypnotist!
Are you all right?
I'm fine. I just remembered something...
About this pass...
You showed me before.
This is the gem that Peagram found in the castle...
So that's what all the fuss was about...
And that's where it belongs!
Do you recognise the man in this photograph?
No, but I wouldn't trust him. His eyes are too close together.
He's not a friend of yours, is he?
Oh, no. Far from it. In fact, I believe it's the face of a killer!
I knew it! Piggy eyes. Can't trust 'em.
I already told you I didn't.
Does this tool mean anything to you?
No, it doesn't. Is it used on sheep?
Never! How?
They'd slip out. Angles all wrong... You'd never do it.
I have! I did it in Paris.
You already showed me that, and I wasn't impressed.
What do you make of this matchbook?
Seems ordinary enough to me.
Would you like to shake my hand?
What is this? I don't do that male bonding stuff!
Come on - forget your prejudice and shake hands...
Never. It's not natural.
What do you think of my flashlight?
Those electric lamps are useful, but limited in lifespan, in my experience.
I was given one for my birthday, but it stopped working after a month.
The battery was probably drained.
What? Nobody told me! I threw it away!
Did I show you my flashlight?
Indeed you did.
What do you make of this tissue?
That is a very unpleasant object indeed.
Excuse me!
Excuse me, Mr Leary!
I fixed your glass washer, no problem.
Bingo, and a blessing to all the saints!
A free half pint to that man, on the house!
Now - could you take a look at the beer pumps?
I guess so, but I'm not making any promises...
If you can't fix them I'll have a riot on my hands!
The pumps are in the cellar, right?
That's right. You'll find a flashlight down there somewhere...
Hey! Where do you think you're going?
Excuse me?
No customers behind the bar! Ever!
Get out!
I could try to fix your glass washer.
Oh, no - not unless you're a qualified electrician...
Don't change the subject!
Are you gonna pay me Peagram's rent or not?
No way!
Listen - I'm not really his friend. I've never even met the guy!
I need to find Peagram - urgently. I think his life is in danger.
Damn right it is!
Excuse me for butting in, Michael, but I think the young fella's telling the truth.
I'm sorry I bit your head off, sir.
That's okay. I understand... I guess.
Top of the morning to you!
I beg your pardon?
That's what you Irish say, isn't it?
Do you want something or are you just flaunting your xenophobia?
Unh... I was trying to be sociable.
Hmph! Is it a room you're after?
No, thank you. I don't plan to stay too long.
Who does? Most folk take one look at Lochmarne and jump back on the bus.
That's not a bad idea. Do you have a vacancy?
I could, if you don't mind waiting until the last guest checks out.
No problem. When will that be?
When the undertaker comes to collect him.
What did you say to get rid of Fitzgerald?
Uh... it was a... misunderstanding.
I've never seen him move so fast.
I could use your help at closing time, clearing the bar!
Yes, sir?
He hadn't heard me...
Well?
Well what?
Are you going to fix this glass washer or not?
What?
I'm still waiting for you to fix this glass washer!
Okay! Keep your hair on!
A glass of beer, please.
I'll try a glass of beer, please.
Is this your first pint of 'real ale'?
Beer that's brewed from natural ingredients to traditional methods.
It shouldn't be kept under pressure, or refrigerated.
And finally, it should have a good body and distinctive character.
In other words, it's flat and warm with bits in and it makes you fall over.
May I have another beer, please?
Certainly, sir! Same again?
That's the secret of the master brewers, sir!
Each barrel is lovingly manhandled in time-honored fashion...
Suspended on skillfully tied ropes of the finest hemp...
Lowered into the cellar utilising the forces of original gravity.
Like manna from heaven!
Hey, how about another drink!
Same again?
Hmm,,, Do you serve cocktails?
I'll serve anyone with manners and money.
I'm serious. Have you considered turning MacDevitts into a cocktail bar?
What? Kids in the bar?! Can you imagine it?
Pinball, pimples and puke!
Gimme another beer, dude!
Give EVERYONE another beer! Let's PARTY, guys!
I think you've had enough, don't you?
Hey, listen - is it supposed to taste the way it does?
More beer, over here!
Yes, sir.
I'm sorry, but the pump appears to be broken!
I could fix it for you!
I don't think so. This is a job for a professional electrician.
Oh well, at least the glass washer is still working...
It's not my day, is it?
What can you tell me about the castle?
You're the second person to ask me that today!
I don't know anything about the castle.
It's only an old ruin anyway.
Who else was asking about the castle?
He said he was a reporter.
He was askin' about the little people!
I could have told him a tale or two about d' liddle people.
He might have paid me to hear what he wanted me to say.
Anyway, I chucked him out on his arse.
Good for you, Mick! That's the way to deal with journalists!
Have you served any, uh... clowns recently?
No, you're the first today.
Seriously - I'm looking for a man dressed in a clown costume.
Would he be having a little white dog with a black patch over the eye?
I shouldn't think so.
What?
Do you know a man called Peagram?
Indeed I do!
Are you a friend of his, by any chance?
In a manner of speaking, I am.
Right, me boyo! A hundred and sixty quid he owes me! Pay up!
That's Peagram's business, not mine.
Ah, but he's done a bunk, hasn't he? Scampered!
I know. That's why I'm here. To look for him.
And what about the money he owes me?
When I find him, I'll remind him about it.
Oh, no. I'm just trying to track him down.
Me too! That son of a bitch should be locked away!
Did Peagram stay here?
Yes, he did! Six nights - plus breakfast.
He couldn'a had breakfast dis morning, not unless he had it afore he went to bed!
What the hell are you talking about, Doyle?
D' history fella - I seen him dis morning, crack o' dawn.
I had t' get up at four o' clock, t' see to d' missus.
I didn't know your wife was sick, Pat!
She's not. Anyhow - I went out to empty d' bucket, and what d'you think I saw?
For the love o' God, Doyle - get to the point!
It was d' history man, headin' out o' d' village - on a bicycle!
I knew it! Hand over my money, or I'll throw you out!
That's right - in the best room in the house.
Dat's d' one wid d' bed.
Can I see Peagram's room?
It's been taken by one of the brothers from the reformatory.
They come every year for spiritual refreshment.
Dat's a good one! Dere idea of refreshment is a gutful of stout!
I wouldn't want to disturb a man of God.
Especially not a big fella from the bad boys' home.
I don't blame you, Mick. Dat brother's got muscles like a muscle-man!
About Fitzgerald...
I'm looking for a man named Fitzgerald.
Fitzy? What's he done?
I believe he may have worked at Peagram's dig.
Sean Fitzgerald? WORK? You've got the wrong guy!
Do you know Sean Fitzgerald very well?
I know him enough not to sell him more than two pints.
He's like a kid when he gets a few beers inside him.
I'm not surprised - he's on medication. For his nerves.
There's nothing wrong with his nerves! He's just screwy.
Aren't you going to see what happened to Fitzgerald?
Why?
D... didn't you hear what the kid said?
The man's been hit by an automobile!
You don't want to listen to Maguire. He's a born liar, and a hooligan!
I'm really concerned for Fitzgerald's safety!
Why? He's probably gone home, unless he's in the ditch.
Don't you care about him? He was real uptight when he left the bar!
And whose fault was that? YOU were talking to him, not me.
That's right, Michael.
It's not wrong you are dere, Mister O'Brien.
Now just a minute, you guys! All I did was ask him about Peagram.
That fella owes me a hundred and eighty quid!
That's a awful lot of money, Michael.
With compound interest, too. It grows with each time o' telling...
Look, I gotta be going...
I don't want anything.
Just give me a shout when you do...
Thanks...
I found your flashlight.
So I see. You'd better keep hold of that until you've fixed the pumps.
Do you recognize this man?
No, I don't. What d'you want with him?
I've got a score to settle...
I don't want any trouble in the bar, mister.
If it's a fight you're looking for, see Father Mahoney.
A priest? A man of the cloth?
Sure, and he teaches the boys how to box at the youth club.
According to Mahoney, it develops character.
Isn't that right, Pat? Didn't he teach you the art of pugilism?
Doyle!
Sorry, Michael. I was miles away. What did you say?
Ah, never mind.
You already asked me that.
Does this false nose mean anything to you?
It's not red nose day again, is it?
I know that! Good god almighty, what d'you take me for?
And before you ask, I haven't seen any clowns in the bar.
No, it doesn't!
Does this piece of wire mean anything to you?
Good god, man - put it away!
What's the problem?
Don't play the innocent with me, mister!
What you do with that wire is your own business, but don't drag me into it!
No, it doesn't.
Here's something which might interest you...
Huh? What is it?
My passport to the sewers of Paris.
Is that so?
Did you see the snooker last night, Mr. O'Brien?
I haven't got a television, Michael.
I take it no-one wants to hear about my underground escapades?
It doesn't.
Do you recognize this matchbook?
No, sir.
Does this...
I knew it! The minute you walked through the door I knew you spelled trouble!
Now just a minute!
It might be what you're used to in New York, but we don't use that stuff here!
Hey, it's plaster! I found it in the castle!
I'm not interested.
Shake my hand...
Hey, bartender!
Landlord, if y' don't mind.
Sorry. Shake my hand, why don't you...
Now why should I do that? What have you got up your sleeve?
Nothing! C'mon, just shake my hand...
Not just now, mister. I have t' be careful on account o' the health restrictions.
Aw, jeez!
Why won't you shake my hand?
Because I don't know where you've been.
Do you recognize the name on this card?
No - should I?
Are you sure you don't recognize this...
I told you - no!
It just so happens I'm an electrician! Check out my credentials..
Well, now, isn't that marvelous?
Here's a house bedeviled with faulty wiring of a wayward nature...
Here's you, an electric man - with a little plastic card t' prove it!
You can make a start on the glass washer.
When you've finished that will you take a look at the pumps...?
Check out my card...
I've seen it, for heaven's sake!
May I borrow this towel?
Sure you can, on one condition...
What's that?
You keep it away from old Ron.
Who's Ron?
That's him in the corner - with the hygiene problem.
You can keep it.
Does this gem mean anything to you?
Phew! What a beauty! I bet you wish that was real, don't you?
Does this tissue mean anything to you?
That's disgusting!
Uh-huh! I found it in the sewers
What's the idea of waving it around in my face?
You're worse than old Ron! Put it away, man!
No, it doesn't.
Hey! I just seen a big red...
Get out of here, Maguire!
Come back when you're old enough!
What's the lad howling about?
A big red sports car!
Sean Fitzgerald's been runned over!
Get OUT!
Noisy little tyke.
Maybe you should send out some medicinal brandy, Michael...
Oh, yes! And who's going to pay for it?
Not me!
Me too, neither!
Hello, there! My name's George Stobbart.
Excuse me, mister O'Brien...
Pleased to meet you I'm sure. I'm O'Brien. Can I help you?
What now?
Hello, there. What now?
Young Fitzgerald seems to have a problem...
Uh... yeah. I don't know what got into him.
He's a strange lad. Gets wrapped up inside himself.
He wasn't listening...
What can you tell me about the castle, Mr O'Brien?
Ah, you're wasting your time.
There's no story there - just a pile of rock and rubble.
It's a fine sight now, isn't it?
Dates back to the tenth century, you know.
Most of the existing building was added much later, of course.
Are the ruins open to the public?
Oh, no - it's much too dangerous.
Anyway there's nothing of interest remaining.
Peagram thought otherwise didn't he?
Ah, but it's not difficult to get them history boys excited is it?
Give them a bone to play with and they're happy as puppies.
Can you tell me about the tripod which was found at the castle?
Now there's a bone of contention and controversy.
It was dug up by an Englishman of the archaeological persuasion.
Who was this Englishman?
Professor Peagram. The same man who dug up the gem...
Was it Peagram who dug up the tripod at the castle?
The same man if he wasn't his twin brother.
And can you guess what he did with the tripod?
He sent it to a museum in Paris. I've seen it.
How can I get into the castle?
Those walls were built specifically to stop people getting in, Mr Stobbart.
But I dare say you'll find a way, if you've the will...
Listen, it's closed, locked, barred and bolted.
The castle is as impenetrable as the walls of Troy.
So I can't get in, then?
My, you're bright for a journalist!
Have you heard of the Phantom?
More than that - I've seen it!
And let me tell you - it's a dreadful spectacle!
So it's not just a local legend?
There really IS a Phantom of Lochmarne?
Oh, no.
I was talking about the Phantom of the Opera.
What can you tell me about the gem which Peagram found?
Now there is a gem which should never have been taken.
A man would have to be full of greed to covet that stone.
What's your interest in the jewel? You're not a reporter, are you?
Yes, that's right.
Another bloody news hound...! Well, you're wasting your time here, boy.
You'll find the people of Lochmarne are a tight-lipped and cautious lot.
Why? Have you got something to hide?
It's just that we don't like to wash our dirty laundry in public.
Oh, no.
Thank the lord for that.
The boy told me Fitzgerald was driven away in the car that hit him.
Maguire is always spinning wild yarns.
I don't know where he gets them from. Television, I expect, or comics.
If I was you, I'd take what he says with a generous pinch of salt.
Maguire's tale about the car sounds quite plausible to me.
He says the driver was dressed like a leprechaun!
That boy has a head full of fluffy toys!
You're too late to meet that fella.
Is he dead?
Not that - but he's gone from the village.
A sore point with our esteemed host, I might add!
Why don't you leave the poor man alone?
I just want to talk to him.
Hound him to death, more likely!
You news boys are all the same.
Do you know where Peagram has gone?
Haven't I made it clear enough to you?
I don't like parasites or things that crawl, and that includes journalists.
I'm sorry but I don't.
He upped anchor in the dark and shipped out before the dawn.
Why did he do that?
Who knows? A guilty conscience, or a secret assignation...
Whatever the reason he'll not be missed in Lochmarne.
Maybe now the fuss about the gem has died down we can get back to normal.
Why has Peagram's departure upset the landlord?
He's lost a paying guest, that's why.
More than that - there's the question of an unsettled bill.
Poor Michael's seen red over the business, and I don't blame him.
Well, why don't you ask him yourself, mister Ace-reporter?
Can you tell me more about the landlord?
Mick Leary? He's what you call a would-be sophisticate.
The trouble is, his idea of sophistication extends as far as putting paper in the lavatory.
I never worked out why he did dat.. It's much too dark in dere to read.
That's true. Have you ever run your hand over the back of the door?
The graffiti is written in braille.
What's your game? Keep your nose out of our business, mister!
Do you know Sean Fitzgerald?
Yes, I do.
What do you want with him?
I want to talk to him about working at the dig.
What makes you think he did?
The boy outside told me.
I can't imagine anyone employing Sean Fitzgerald on a dig.
He wouldn't know a post hole from his elbow!
I'm not telling you anything, mister.
You can dig up your own dirt!
If he's been hit by a car, he could be injured...
It's high time there was stiffer legislation against careless motorists.
What we need is a by-pass around d' village.
One o' dem ring roads - like d' M-twenty-five!
I don't wish to comment on it - not in front of a hack like you.
God knows how you'll twist the tale of the poor lad's mishap!
What happened to him? What's he twisted?
Hush, Pat! This devil will steal the words out of your gob while they're still steaming!
I have a suspicion that Fitzgerald might have been given something by Peagram...
I thought he acted strangely!
I'm talking about the gem. It was something he said...
Were you not speaking to him when he ran out of the bar?
I only asked him about the gem...
Fitzgerald has troubles enough already.
He's a nervous, unstable man at the best of times.
The last thing he needs is to be harassed by a hack newsboy!
Yeah, sure - just talking, that's all...
Journalists! You've no conscience, have you?
Have you ever heard of the Knights Templar?
I most certainly have! A remarkable institution.
Did you know they were the originators of our system of credit?
Their financial empire stretched from the Atlantic to the Caspian Sea.
With bases in so many countries they had to establish new methods of fiscal transferal.
So the Knights Templar were nothing but a bunch of bankers!
I don't get it. Are you sayin' dese Templar guys invented bank charges?
In a manner of speaking, I suppose they did.
What a dirty trick! Didn't anyone try to stop dem?
Oh, yes. They were arrested, and many were burnt at the stake!
Good! Dey bloody well deserved it if dey were anythin' like MY bank manager!
Oh, nothing...
Goodbye for now...
Good riddance to you!
Does this towel mean anything to you?
Sure - it's one of Leary's towels. Are you planning on stealing it?
Just borrowing it, if you must know.
Did I show you this towel?
Yes, you did.
Does this red nose suggest anything to you?
O'Donnelly and I walked all the way to Ballymore - fifteen miles in our bare feet.
No, it doesn't.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
No. I've never seen him before.
What do you make of this piece of wire?
It looks ordinary enough to me...
Do you recognize this gem?
Ah, that's a beautiful stone. Is it the one which Peagram found?
Yeah - and the reason why both he and Fitzgerald have disappeared.
Then it's only a matter of time before you vanish too.
Yes, you've already shown me that.
What can you tell me about this ID pass?
Does this tool mean anything to you?
I'd say it was for lifting manhole covers.
How come you know that?
I'm a man of the world, Mr Stobbart.
I told you - it's for lifting manhole covers.
Does this matchbook mean anything to you?
The design is Middle Eastern, I'd say.
What do you make of this white powder?
Could it be bicarborunderate of soda?
I'd like to shake you by the hand, Mr O'Brien...
I'd rather not. You see, I happened to notice that vibrating buzzer in your palm...
Oh, no, you don't!
What do you make of this tissue?
I'd guess that muck on it is greasepaint.
There's no fooling you, Mr O'Brien.
Did I show you this tissue?
Yes. It's truly disgusting.
What do you think of this flashlight?
It's not a very practical piece of equipment, is it?
It's not switched on.
I'm referring to the lack of a bracket.
How would you be fixing that to your bicycle?
I don't have a bicycle.
I've told you already.
Leave it!
Will you leave it alone, man?
Look, I know how it seems, but my curiosity got the better of me.
Keep your hands to yourself, mister!
Hey, I only wanted to...
Can't! Hands off!
Oh no you don't!
Okay! I'm sorry!
Hi there, old timer!
Hello, again...
Nasty cold you've got there!
As soon as the words left my lips I regretted them.
Is there such a thing as a cold which isn't nasty?
I put the question to Father Mahoney
Father, says I, why were we born to suffer snot?
What did he say?
He said it's my reward for being out all night like a sinner.
Pious prig.
Anyway - this is no ordinary cold - 'tis the Hay Fever.
Pollinosis?
Thank you. You're not a policeman, are you?
Excuse me?
Police. No - I'd know it if you were...
I guess he hadn't heard me...
Can I buy you a beer?
Very kind, I'm sure, but I don't drink the stuff Leary sells.
What's wrong with it?
I've seen what it can do.
Can you tell me how to get into the castle?
That's what the kid outside told me, but I don't believe it!
Then you're a fool.
Ghosts don't bother me. I still want to visit the castle.
You can't. It's not open to the public.
There's no-one around to stop me, is there?
That's right. Nothing human, anyhow...
Do you know Peagram, the archaeologist?
No, I don't know him.
Do you know where I can find Peagram?
I told you, I never heard of him!
I'm looking for Sean Fitzgerald... have you seen him?
Never heard o' him!
Don't you come from 'round here?.
None o' your business. I didn't ask where you come from, did I?
I'm from California.
That's your problem.
Did you ever see Fitzgerald at Peagram's dig?
I never heard of either of 'em.
Aren't you concerned about what happened to Fitzgerald?
No.
Were you aware that Peagram was conducting an archaeological dig?
I don't meddle in other people's affairs. They don't interest me.
Have you ever seen the ghost?
To be sure - with me very own eyes!
Can you describe the ghost?
It was horrible! A wee stunted beast  - long beak, straggly, flappy wings...
Are you sure it wasn't a wild animal - a rabbit or a... skunk, or something?
Skunk? In Lochmarne? That'll be the day...
No, that was a ghost to be sure.
I think I know what you saw on the castle wall...
I know what I saw.
I don't think so. It was the kid, Maguire.
What?!
He was up on the wall last Tuesday night.
He thought YOU were the Phantom of Lochmarne!
Oh.
What's that you're making?
Oh, sure. Made out of steel wire?
Heh-heh! That's right - a necklace for my pretty one!
When my little lover feels it round her slender neck she'll be mine, all mine!
HEH-HEH-HEH-HEH!
If I was a woman I wouldn't think much of a wire necklace...
It's not made for a woman!
I've got my sights on tastier dishes than women!
Flesh as smooth and tender as a maiden's!
Bones as soft and white as a new-born babe's!
Rabbit, lad. That's what gets my juices flowin'!
HEH-HEH-HEH-HEH!
That's right. Do you have a problem with that?
Damned right I do! Isn't it painful?
Only if I get my fingers caught.
I'm talking about the rabbits! Do they feel much pain?
You bet!
HEH-HEH-HEH-HEH!
See you later...
What do you think of this flashlight?
Very useful.
That could be very handy in the dark.
How much do you want for it?
It's not for sale. It belongs to Leary.
Did I show you this flashlight?
Yes, you did.
Could you use this towel?
I could, but it wouldn't be much use for anything else!
What does this red nose mean to you?
I suppose you're collecting for charity...
No, I'm not. I want to know if you've seen someone wearing a nose like this.
No, I haven't.
Nothin'.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
Is that supposed to be you?
No. I don't have a scar on my face, and I'm not from the Middle East.
Here - this wire belongs to you.
Oh, no. Never saw it before, no.
What does this gem mean to you?
Well, well - would you look at that. Pretty.
Do you recognize it?
No.
Take a look at this ID card...
Take a look... Oh, yes - little plastic picture.
I don't suppose it means anything to you, does it?
No.
I don't know anythin' about it.
Can you identify this tool?
No.
What does this matchbook mean to you?
Nothing. Go away and stop bothering me.
What do you make of this white powder...?
Arrrgh!
Hay fever!
You could make use of this tissue...
Never use 'em. Those things are unhygienic.
Just my luck! Grassed up by a delinquent and a dimwit!
What do you mean? Is he in danger?
Yeah - you too, if I'm right.
You're not from the Social Security?
Hell, no. What makes you think that?
Well, I was claiming benefit at the same time I was working for Peagram.
I'm not in a position to make judgment, Sean.
That's between you and your conscience.
All I want is to talk to Peagram about the gem.
But he's not here!
I know that, but he left that package with you, didn't he?
He hadn't heard me...
Mister Fitzgerald?
I need to speak with you, urgently.
Wh... what's the problem?
My name's George.
Pleased to meet you, mister.
Are you Sean Fitzgerald?
Unh, that's... that's right.
My name's Fitzgerald.
Hello.
What can you tell me about the castle?
There's nothing there, just an old ruin.
How old?
I really couldn't tell you.
Have you ever explored the castle yourself?
I used to play there sometimes, when I was a kid.
Then one of the littlun's fell off the wall, broke his head and died...
We didn't go there any more.
You haven't been up there recently?
No.
What did Peagram find at the castle?
The entrance to an underground chamber.
It was filled with earth and rubble, and Peagram had us dig it out.
We uncovered a secret room - a hidden chapel...
Did Peagram find the gem in the altar room?
I don't know! He made us leave, and wouldn't tell us why.
Half an hour later he came out. White as a sheet he was.
He closed down the dig and locked up the castle. Sent us all away.
From the sound of it, Peagram had discovered more than just the gem...
He's the archaeologist, isn't he?
That's right.
I heard he's gone fishing.
I don't know where...
So where did Peagram go?
I don't know, I swear it.
He came to see me, early this morning. Said he was leaving.
He asked me to give this package to a guy called Marquet.
Ha-ha! What gave you that idea?
Maguire says you did.
You don't believe that damned hooligan do you?
Why not?
His probation officer could tell you a tale or two.
Maguire says he SAW you working at the dig...
What's more, he saw you talking with Peagram.
He's a little liar! He'll say anything to get attention.
Well, it's his word against yours, I guess.
I knew this would happen. I knew I'd get caught...
Doyle told me you definitely worked at the dig.
He's seen you there. You might as well admit it.
You don't believe HIM, do you?
Patrick Doyle is a moron and a scoundrel.
Even so, he saw you talking to Peagram.
You can't prove that, mister!
Have you heard about the gem which Peagram found?
I heard a rumor, but you can't believe everything you hear or see, can you?
Can I get you another drink?
Oh - no, thank you! I shouldn't be drinking at all.
I'm on tablets for my nerves. More than a pint and I'll pass out!
Show me what's in the package, Sean...
I... I can't do that.
Why not?
I promised the Professor.
So what? You didn't have any qualms about your benefit scam...
...so where's the harm in taking a peek inside Peagram's package?
You don't know these people! I can't! I don't dare!
This is your last chance to show me the package, Fitzgerald.
I've been patient with you, but now it's time to kick ass.
But he'll kill me!
Who will?
The man from Paris - Jacques Marquet.
Peagram told me if I gave him the package, unopened, I'd hear no more about it.
But if I double crossed Marquet, I'd be dead.
I'll deal with Jacques Marquet.
Give the package to me.
No! Why should I trust you?
I don't know who to trust any more!
I wish I'd never even HEARD of the Lochmarne gem!
Sorry to bother you...
See you later...
Ever seen this towel before?
Very observant, Fitzgerald.
What does this red nose suggest to you?
Blood!
Why is that?
I used to bleed a lot when I was a kid.
Every time there was a playground scrap I'd end up with a bloody nose.
I wouldn't have minded, but I wasn't even involved in the scraps.
Nothing.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
Uh... no, at least I don't think so.
Look closely - he has a scar on his face...
No, I'm sure I don't know him.
What do you suppose this wire is used for?
How should I know?
Check out this pass...
Yeah. It's yours, is it?
Not exactly... Do you recognize the name?
Thomas Moerlin... No, never heard of him.
What do you think this tool is used for?
Uh... something to do with horses?
Wrong. It's for opening manhole covers.
Oh. Really? Well, you learn something every day.
Did I show you this tool?
Yes, you did.
Does this matchbook mean anything to you?
No.
Shake my hand.
It's a trick, isn't it?
Dammit, you're right. I can't seem to fool anyone...
What does this tissue suggest to you?
Nothing...
I can't see why, meself. Why men would fight and steal and kill over a little bauble like that.
Well... it's kinda neat the way it sparkles.
No, it's for lifting the covers off drains.
Well, the end of the tool fits into the hole in the cover...
Yeah.
Uh, well... I guess so! What's 'real ale', anyhow?
Yes, please. How is this stuff made?
Cocktails are chic, cool, and popular with younger drinkers!
Right - I get the picture. I'll settle for a glass of stout.
Na Gopaleen's stout is brewed from the finest chemicals in the world!
Uh... I don't know. This is part of a clown's costume.
I know that. Why is it, if y' don't mind me askin'?
If God had meant us to watch television we'd all be like Doyle...
I'd rather drink me own beer.
Nah. It was a long shot.
Hmm... I still want to see what you can do before I let you touch me beer pumps...
Don't even think about it, me bucko. Lochmarne castle... is haunted!
That's the scrawny fella who was pokin' around at the castle, isn't it?
It's a necklace, me bucko.
Ah! So you're making snares to trap rabbits.
I can't tell without me glasses.
Hey! Would you like to shake my, unh... No, on second thoughts, forget it.
I need to talk to Professor Peagram, if he's still alive.
Do you know Professor Peagram?
Where can I find Professor Peagram?
Did you work at Professor Peagram's dig?
Somehow, I'd managed to drink the thick, sweet brew.
I used all my knowledge of electrical engineering to examine the plug.
Doesn't it belong on the bar...?
It's usually me who makes a complete ass of himself.
One pint o' brown, comin' up!
I know it! Dat's where d' prunes come from!
Do I know him? Do I know d' good professor himself?
Such craft must surely come from d' linen cupboards of the Vatican itself!
Do you recognise this white powder?
Seems ordinary enough to me.
Do you know Professor Peagram?
Do you know where I could find Professor Peagram?
Don't you think we should go help Fitzgerald?
It's a clown's nose, isn't it? I haven't been to a circus since I was ten years old...
He wasn't listening...
What a dumb place to store a flashlight - a dark cellar!
The only way I was going to find anything down there was to feel around...
Now I could see, I spotted Mr Leary's flashlight easily.
Then I noticed a flash of light, something sparkling beneath the open trapdoor...
It was Peagram's gem all right: a large, uncut, blue stone.
As I held it aloft I realized the fascination it could command...
I guess I was already under its spell.
It was a rusty faucet.
The faucet creaked, coughed and spewed out a stream of rusty colored water.
I shut off the faucet as tight as I could, but it kept on dripping.
I held the towel under the faucet and soaked it with water.
The towel was already as wet as it was going to get...
The slow drip of water barely dampened the towel.
My hand closed on a long metal rod...
It was the lever which locked the trapdoor.
I pushed the lever and heard the grating of metal, but nothing appeared to happen...
I pulled the lever and the bolt creaked back into place.
I tried to pull the lever, but it wouldn't move with the trapdoor open.
It was an empty carton which had once contained caustic soda.
The carton was damp and soggy. Useless.
It was a calendar with a faded photograph of a prize winning carp...
I tried to turn the pages, but they were matted together with mold and mildew.
It was a bunch of cleaning materials.
I looked among the cleaning materials, but saw nothing I could use.
It was a couple of paper sacks filled with trash.
I searched the trash, but there was nothing useful there.
Did you find it?
What?
Whatever you was lookin' for.
Uh... yeah. Listen, Maguire - I want you to keep this to yourself.
No problemo. Jus' chuck us up a crate o' lager.
No way. You're not old enough.
We can sell it an' make some cash!
Forget it, kid. I couldn't  betray Mr Leary's trust.
I could, for sure! That ol' misery-guts deserves it!
If you want to do me a favor, keep a look out for that guy in the suit...
Okay, but it'll cost you a packet o' chips!
...and shout if you see that Ferrari!
The farmer's craggy face was set in a mask of aesthetic appreciation.
His feet were set in a pair of manure-caked boots.
The gates were made of solid, age-blackened wood.
The gates were comfortingly solid - but I still felt nervous at the thought of that goat lurking the other side.
Pushing with all my strength got me nowhere. They didn't budge. I really need to start working out.
Great for drain covers, useless for castle gates.
I didn't have the first idea how to pick a lock.
On the back of the cart was a crazily stacked tower of hay bales, leaning precariously against the castle wall.
Even if I did have a match, I wasn't about to set fire to the hay.
Get down, you lemming-brained lummock!
Don't climb on the cart, pea-brain!
Get away, you silly noodle!
Can't you see the load's unstable?
Hi!
Do you speak English?
Well now - what if I was to say no?
An implication of cognizance shrouded in denial - a pretty poser of a paradox indeed.
I gave him the look I'd perfected when I was twelve and was going to be the greatest hypnotist of all time.
It was a killer.
Are you attempting to hypnotize me or is it the constipation you're suffering?
It's me again...
So I see. What now?
He was totally engrossed in the book he was reading...
Good book?
A book? It's a passport to a world of fantasy and imagination...
Yeah? What's the title?
Creative shelving for beginners - the 1978 edition.
What's so cool about home improvement?
There's nothing like it.
The resinous autumnal aroma of seasoned wood, the rhythmic rasp of the plane...
Ah, no wonder Our Lord came to earth as the son of a humble carpenter.
I'll bet he was a wizard with a chisel and a length of two by four...
Surely the portrayal of Christ's adoptive family as humble artisans is a symbolic metaphor?
I don't know about that, but I know they were carpenters.
Haven't you read the book?
Well, no, but I saw `The Greatest Story Ever Told', and I don't recall Jesus putting up any shelves...
What can you tell me about the castle?
Not much, I'm sorry to say. Most of its history is long forgotten.
Ah, but if these old stones could only speak, what stories they'd tell...
Stories to make your toes curl and your blood run cold!
You know, this castle is said to be over six hundred years old!
Who built the castle?
Mad Phelan, the first lord of Lochmarne!
Well, I say lord, but actually he was little more than a village chieftain.
He built his castle from the remains of the Templar Preceptory.
Do you mind if I climb up your hay stack to get into the castle?
What? You'd break your stupid neck, for sure!
Do you think I'd stand by and see your brains dashed out?
I'd be very careful, and I promise not to sue.
You won't get the chance, not while I'm here to stop you.
Did you happen to see a red sports car down on the road?
I caught a glimpse of a flash of red on the hill and heard the racket!
Sure it was an awful noise. A sports car, you say?
A Ferrari, to be exact.
A racing car? And what was it doing here?
The poor fella must have been lost!
The driver of the Ferrari was involved in an accident.
Is that so?
Yeah - he knocked somebody down outside the bar.
What an idiot! How could a thing like that happen?
He was traveling too fast.
So fast he ran right under the car?
I mean the car was traveling too fast.
But you'd have thought the idiot could have heard it coming!
Did you notice which way the car was traveling?
To hazard a guess I'd say it was forward.
But which direction did it leave the village?
East. Does it matter?
Sure it does. That's where the kidnapper has taken Sean.
Ah, ha - we've got him for sure, like a cornered rat!
That road leads to one place only - straight to Dublin.
Maybe you know the guy who was hit by the Ferrari?
His name is Sean Fitzgerald.
Oh, I know him all right.
That's my nephew - the idiot responsible for the stacking of my hay cart.
Was he killed by the car?
Well, that's a relief now.
Aren't you going to look for your nephew?
What for? From what you say, it's too late.
You could report the matter to the police.
Better not. Besides, what could they do?
They have only the one bicycle between them.
I'm not sure I want to know!
But you're his uncle, his own flesh and blood!
You're right, but what can I do?
If I'm not here to guard it, some idiot might try to climb the hay stack!
What a moral dilemma!
To stay here and guard this potentially lethal agricultural construction...
Or to go off in search of the prodigal nephew, the very man responsible for said hazard?
It'll need some thinkin' about.
Why, there's no problem.
You're right. Why didn't I think of it before?
We'll demolish the haystack.
You don't have to demolish the haystack to go look for Sean.
I'll stay here in your place and warn anyone who's silly enough to climb it...
Marvelous! I think I should start my enquiries in the bar...
He strode off in the direction of MacDevitts bar, leaving me to contemplate the stack of hay.
Have you heard of the Phantom of Lochmarne?
I have, and it's not true.
That's what I figured. You have to be pretty dumb to believe in ghosts.
Oh, I believe in ghosts - I just don't happen believe in this ghost.
No. He's packed up and gone.
Do you happen to know where?
Do you think Peagram's disappearance is due to the curse?
Look at the facts: he dug up the gem, he disappeared. Bingo!
It doesn't take a degree in mathematics to work that one out, does it?
You don't have to be a smarty Pythagorus with a calculator!
I guess not.
Peagram has run off with the gem!
Where was the site of the Templar preceptory?
Right here - on Temple hill.
Phelan built right on top of the old walls.
It's said that deep beneath these walls, there's a Templar chapel.
Did Peagram discover the chapel?
I don't know. His workers were sworn to secrecy.
Have you read about Peagram's discovery?
The gem? Oh, yes.
Did you get to see it?
No, he didn't show it to us.
Oh, nothing...
I have to go now.
Whatever gave you that idea? Oh dear, oh dear me, no.
Does this curiously twisted piece of wire mean anything to you?
Oh dear. Now what would you be wanting with a cruel snare like that?
It's not mine! It belongs to the old guy in the bar...
Ah, yes - it would.
Is this wire intended to be used as a snare?
That's right.
This is the gem that Peagram found in the castle...
So that's what all the fuss was about...
I can't see why, myself. Why men would fight and steal and kill over a little bauble like that.
It's kinda neat the way it sparkles...
And that's where it belongs!
Does this false nose mean anything to you?
You're a circus clown.
No, but I got this from someone who disguised himself as a clown.
Is that a fact? Why did he do that now?
He's a psychotic killer. I think he may be connected with Peagram's disappearance.
Yes, you did.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
No, but I wouldn't trust him. His eyes are too close together.
He's not a friend of yours, is he?
Oh, no. Far from it. In fact, I believe it's the face of a killer!
I knew it! Piggy eyes. Can't trust 'em.
I already told you I didn't.
Do you recognize the name on this card?
I can't read that little writing!
Is that your name? Tommy Merlin?
No...
But what a great stage name! It had what my high-school hypnosis act had lacked: style and class!
For a few seconds I bathed in spot lights on a thundering tide of applause: Tommy Merlin, Hypnotist!
Are you all right?
I'm fine. I just remembered something...
About this pass...
You showed me before.
Does this tool mean anything to you?
No, it doesn't. Is it used on sheep?
No, its for lifting the covers off drains.
Never! How?
The end of the tool fits into a hole in the cover...
They'd slip out. Angle's all wrong... You'd never do it.
I have! I did it in Paris.
You already showed me that, and I wasn't impressed.
What do you make of this matchbook?
Seems ordinary enough to me.
What do you make of this tissue?
That's a sorry sight to wave about in public!
Oh, it's theatrical greasepaint.
And that makes it all right, does it?
I must remember that next time someone complains about the state of my handkerchief...
Would you like to shake my hand?
What is this? I don't do that male bonding stuff!
Come on - forget your prejudice and shake hands...
Never. It's not natural.
What do you think of my flashlight?
Those electric lamps are useful, but limited in lifespan, in my experience.
I was given one for my birthday, but it stopped working after a month.
The battery was probably drained.
What? Nobody told me! I threw it away!
Did I show you my flashlight?
Indeed you did.
Do you know anything about this piece of wire?
It looks like a hand made snare.
Have you any use for this towel?
Did I show you this nose?
I was a little out of practice...
No. But he has been abducted.
Well, they could mount a search!
In a question of superior acceleration, I'd put me money on the Ferrari...
I think you ought to know exactly what Sean has gotten himself into...
Have you seen Professor Peagram?
Back in England, I suppose.
The stack of hay stopped short of the top of the wall.
Even if I stretched as far as I could, the wall was out of reach.
What I needed was a slice or two of Alice's Wonderland...
There was a narrow crack between two of the stones where the centuries-old mortar had crumbled away.
I pushed my fingers into the narrow crack. It went back several inches into the rock.
Above my head was a gap in the wall where the massive stones had fallen away.
The lifting key was rammed tightly into the crack in the wall forming a strong foothold.
I tugged at the lifting key and found it was held quite securely.
It remained lodged in the wall, jutting out to form a step.
I inserted the end of the lifting key in the mortarless crack and gave it a firm shove.
The goat was tangled up with the old plow.
It was the fiercest, meanest looking old goat I'd ever laid eyes upon.
The goat's movements were restricted by a halter tied to a metal post.
The top of a ladder rose out of the squarely dug hole.
It was a rusted piece of iron, maybe part of a plow or something.
The rope by which the goat was tethered had become tangled on the old plow share...
No way was I going near that old goat!
Hey, Billy!
The animal fixed on me with an evil glare.
Behind the malice and resentment there was a cool intelligence.
How ya doing, boy?
I felt as threatened as I'd been by the assassin and his goons in Paris...
The goat responded with a cool and penetrating stare.
Behind the altar was a carved panel, decorated with animals, birds and plants.
A flight of stairs led down into darkness.
I tried in vain to move the panel...
There was a pattern of five holes arranged on the wall. They'd been drilled there deliberately.
The plaster replica was held against the wall by the pins slotted into the matching sockets.
The hardened plaster cast fitted snugly into the five matching sockets. There was a soft thud, then silence...
I placed my fingers and thumb into the holes in the wall. Nothing happened.
The fragile replica was jammed into the sockets in the wall. I decided not to disturb it.
The faucet was old and rusty and probably hadn't been used for centuries.
The faucet turned reluctantly. There wasn't a drop of water in the pipe.
It was a statue which had fallen from its place on the wall.
Five fingers of stone projected from the back of the carving.
The statue lay face up in the soft sand.
The statue was too heavy to lift. It overbalanced into the sand...
As I swung the stone upright I noticed it had left a pattern of holes in the sand...
I swung the stone back to its original position.
The plaster cast was a pretty neat replica of the back of the stone, complete with protruding fingers.
I placed the fragile plaster cast back on the ground...
I eased the solid piece of plaster from the sand.
Underneath, it had formed a perfect copy of the statue.
The sack contained a fine white powder.
The sack was empty.
As I dipped my fingers into the soft white powder I realized what it was.
Plaster of Paris! I'd used it in kindergarten to make casts of animal paw prints.
I reached into the sack, but it was empty.
I squeezed the towel over the sack but I couldn't extract any moisture from it..
I watched the water soak into the powder. It didn't achieve anything.
The five fingers on the back of the statue had left their impressions in the fine sand.
The patch of sand where the statue had fallen was covered with a dense sprinkling of plaster.

The guy seemed to be practising his air of authority. Today he was working on his withering stare.
The young man's fresh face was full of eagerness and enthusiasm. I figured he was fresh from college.
Excuse me...
Is this the Hagenmeyer clinic?
That's correct.
I thought I was in a garden center...
Oh, the plants! They were my idea.
A little greenery to evoke the spirit of nature!
How may I help you?
I'm here to see Jacques Marquet.
Oh, yes.
No. I'm conducting a private investigation.
Then I can't help you.
Yeah - I'm his, uh... long-lost brother.
A brother half his age, with a different name and an American accent?
I've never heard anything so ridiculous in all my life!
I guess not.
So, do I get to see Marquet before the funeral?
That attitude will get you nowhere!
My instructions were quite clear: no-one gets to see Marquet.
So, unless you can prove you're a relative or a close acquaintance, you're wasting your time here.
Has Marquet had a visit from a pair of gangsters?
I should hope not! Can you describe them?
A thin guy who looks like a weasel, and his friend, the gorilla.
It sounds as if they escaped from a zoo!
Has Marquet been visited by a man in a clown costume?
Oh, no.
You haven't seen a man in disguise?
Well, there's Theodore the Bear. He comes every Thursday, to entertain the children.
If I was stuck on my back with tubes in every orifice, he's the last person I'd want to see.
What's so bad about nurse Grendel?
She runs that ward like a South American prison!
Keeping a well disciplined ward isn't a crime, is it?
Well disciplined?
In the discipline and punishment stakes she'd whip the butt off the Marquis de Sade!
Everything, I mean everything, is done to a strict routine.
Six o'clock: alarm call.
Six-ten: bowel movements, and woe betide anyone who doesn't have a result!
Those patients of hers are like Pavlova's dogs!
She sounds like a real nightmare...
And then some!
If nurse Grendel is that bad, how come the authorities tolerate her?
She's like part of the furniture.
I was beginning to get the picture. This woman was jealous, with a big green capital `J'.
How do I find nurse Grendel's ward?
Down the corridor on the left, turn right at the Senior Consultants' washroom...
...and right again at the executive coffee lounge.
...and turn left at the end. That's J-Two - and good luck!
Oh, it doesn't matter...
Thanks for your help, ma'am
You're welcome!
Does this ball mean anything to you?
No, dear.
What does this false nose remind you of?
Ah! It's a clown's nose!
What does this gem suggest to you?
I advise you not to flash that around.
The hospital insurance wouldn't cover it if it was stolen...
What does this tool suggest to you?
Is it a crack detector?
Huh?
Polar explorers use them to poke about in the snow...
Have you heard of the Club Alamut?
No. It sounds romantic, doesn't it?
The kind of place where you get little umbrellas and whelks...
Huh? That's romantic?
Is this plaster any use to you?
I'm allergic to plaster.
I'd like to return this device...
Not to me you don't.
I don't touch medical equipment, especially if you've used it on sick people.
I'd like to shake you by the hand...
Don't be fresh, young man.
Do you recognize this cup?
Mine's the blue one with the stains - I've tried everything I can to get them out.
Even tried sterilizing it, but it's still the same.
That one looks as if it could do with a good scrub.
Can you think of any use for this greasy tissue?
I guess you could use it to baste a roast turkey...
I've got a toilet chain from a bar in Syria...
No kidding?
A toilet chain?
From Syria?
You sad man.
Do you know anything about this tripod?
If I was you, I'd be careful who you show that thing to.
It looks like the one which was stolen from the Crune!
What do you make of this?
I know what that is.
It's a contact lens for a myopic cow.
Nurse Grendel will be so pleased you've found it.
Did I show you this lens?
Yes, you did.
Have you seen this man here at the clinic?
No, m'sieur, and I never forget a face.
Look at this ID pass...
So you're Moerlin?
Marquet has been asking for you!
For me?
Yes! He was shouting your name when they brought him in here!
Now let me see...
He was on ward B-Twelve, as I recall...
Oh! He's been transferred to...
Oh dear. He's on ward J-Two.
That's...
Nurse Grendel's ward!
Yes, dear - you showed me already.
Stop! Come here!
What's the problem, gramps?
Where do you think you're sloping off to?
Excuse me, sir...
Hi! My name's George Stobbart!
Ah-ha! Just the man...!
Really.
If you wish to make an appointment, see the receptionist.
You must be the new boy.
Uh... yeah, I must be.
Well, stop wandering about and make yourself useful...
Bunny! Come here, boy.
This is Benoir, my nephew.
Can I trust you to look after him?
Do your own baby-sitting, gramps.
Who do you think you are, anyhow?
I am Felix Hagenmeyer.
And may I say what an honor it is to meet you in person, sir.
You're on my Medical Wall of Fame, right up there with Pasteur and Leary!
I look on it as a privilege, no - an honor, to look after your nephew, sir.
He's fresh out of medical school.
It will open his eyes to see a real doctor on the job...
I'll bet!
Show him around. Let him see some real suffering!
I'm looking for a guy named Jacques Marquet.
In which department does he work?
He doesn't. He's a patient.
I see.
You do realize there are strict policies regarding visiting hours, don't you?
Lost him, have you? Don't worry about it.
He'll turn up. Have you tried physio?
Whenever I lose a patient that's the first place I check out.
This is important. I have to talk to Marquet urgently.
We make no exceptions to the rules.
It's a matter of life and death!
The well-oiled running of this hospital is a matter of life and death!
That's why we have rules.
I think I ought to warn you that Marquet is not what he seems...
Explain yourself.
He's in league with a bunch of guys who want to take over the world.
Nonsense!
Could you tell me who Marquet's employers are?
Certainly not!
So long, Hagenmeyer.
Thanks for your help.
Would you like this ball?
Do you recognize this red nose, sir?
No, I do not.
This is a hospital, not a circus ring.
We minister to the sick in body, not the sick in mind.
Does this old cup mean anything to you?
What the devil is it?
It's the communion chalice of the de Vasconcellos.
There are rules about the use of devotional equipment on hospital property...
Did I show you this chalice?
Yes, you did.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
No, sir, I do not.
Look at this, doc. It's a genuine Medieval type gemstone.
Yes, so I see.
Remarkable.
I have to take this gem to Marquet.
He might be able to explain its significance.
My dear chap, Marquet has other things on his mind right now.
Like what?
His catheter, for one.
The gem is yours if you'll let me visit Marquet.
I couldn't consider it.
Now if you were to offer hard cash...
Does the name Thomas Moerlin mean anything to you?
No, it does not.
Does this tool mean anything to you?
It is?
I had to improvise with a knitting needle and a couple of corks.
If only you'd been on hand at the time...
My patient would have given his right arm for it!
Yes. I really must get one like it myself...
Have you ever heard of the Club Alamut?
No, sir, I have not.
Does this white powder mean anything to you?
No, sir. I do not pretend to know the pharmacist's job.
Look what Nurse Grendel gave me, sir.
Ah, yes. Very good. I'm glad to see you're carrying it with you.
It reassures the public to see the medical profession using traditional, archaic tools.
Yes, yes - you told me.
May I have the honor of shaking you by the hand?
You may not. I don't encourage physical contact between my staff.
What do you make of this tissue, sir?
I thought I knew the ins and outs of the human body, but this has me beat.
If I were you I'd have this sample analyzed.
Did I show you this tissue?
Yes, you did.
Is this chain any use to you?
No.
Does this tripod mean anything to you?
No, it does not.
Yes, sir?
Are you related to our client, sir?
Yeah. People always say that. I blame mom.
We were separated at an early age, after a mix-up in the nursery at the Oakland Shopping Mall.
Personally, I think he half scares them to death in that crummy old bear suit.
Oh, you mean she's been here a long time?
That's right!
Why don't you give me a break and go play with someone else?
Ah! Uh... no.
It's not mine, my dear.
Get back to work immediatement!
Besides, Marquet's employers have paid, in advance, for one of our most exclusive private rooms.
Certainly not! The playing of ball games on hospital properties is prohibited.
Sacre Bleu! That's exactly what I needed in my last operation!
No, I mean there's not a man in this clinic who hasn't sprawled out on her.
Bear left past the Administrators' sauna...
As I turned the corner I saw the source of the hellish noise which echoed through the corridors.
It was an industrial polishing machine with an odd-looking guy in tow...
The door didn't have a sign or label, or any kind of identification.
It was the door to the store cupboard.
I was about to open the cupboard when I heard the janitor returning...
The connector in the socket supplied electricity to the polishing machine.
As I tugged the plug out of the socket the polishing machine coughed, spluttered and died.
It was a classic example of functionalism, like an early Soviet spacecraft.
I almost expected to see a dog or a monkey leap out...
I wasn't in the mood for shining floors...
He looked blissfully happy, for no apparent reason.
The janitor's face was a mask of sadness and pain, like his best friend had just died...
It was a life-sized marble figure of a guy in robes.
The sculptor had tried to give him a look of paternal authority and concern.
To my mind he looked just plain constipated.
There was no way I could improve on the sculpture with the janitor watching me.
I didn't think it would suit him somehow...
I guess the water cooler was for the use of people lost in the corridors...
Maybe the face of the unaccountably happy domestic had made me unduly suspicious...
I mean, I knew it was only my imagination, but that water tasted, well - peculiar...
Hmm. Doctor Stobbart, at your service.
No.
See you later...
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
What does this tissue suggest to you?
Hey...!
Okay...
Hey, I asked you not to go in there!
I know, but I'm curious.
Oh, no! I'm responsible for that cupboard and the contents.
Okay...
Hey, now - you can't go in there.
How come?
I'm responsible for the contents of that cupboard.
Take that, you stubborn tin can!
Not again! This is not a good day!
Mr. Shiny! What's wrong, pal?
Hello!
What's that?
I said: Hello!
Oh - hiya!
I'd like to talk to you for a minute...
That's what I thought you said.
Don't look so down-in-the-mouth!
No matter how bad things seem, I never let life get on top of me!
Oh, yeah? What's your secret?
Why - it's easy! All you have to do is smile - and whistle this little tune...
It's a deal!
Oh, hi!
No whistling, right?
Right.
Do you know where I'd find a patient called Marquet?
No. I'm not allowed on the wards with Mr. Shiny.
No, sir, I haven't, but I've got nothing to worry about.
What's that, Mr. Shiny? You'd take good care of the rascals? I'll bet you would!
With a friend like him I've no fear of oppressors!
It must be a great comfort.
He is.
Would `Mr. Shiny' be your polishing machine, by any chance?
Please - don't call him that. He's more of a friend than a machine.
I've had Mr. Shiny for three years, and he's never let me down once!
How come you got so attached to a polishing machine?
I asked you not to call him that.
He's got a name, you know.
Uh... yeah. Mr. Shiny.
It's just that...
You think it's odd, don't you?
No - I, uh...
I don't mind. The rest of the staff think I'm twisted.
I heard them, snorking behind my back when I gave Mr. Shiny his weekly pull-through...
Whatever you've got with this metal mop-foot is probably a fine and noble thing.
It is? Say - it's not every day I meet someone as crazy as me!
Are you having trouble with Mr. Shiny?
Yes, I am! I don't know what's got into him today.
He keeps pullin' his plug.
Do you know a nurse called Grendel?
Sure I do.
Is she on duty today?
Yeah. End of the corridor - ward J-Two.
What's the problem with nurse Grendel?
She's uptight and twisted, on account of a broken heart.
Aw, that's too bad. I thought she was just plain bad-tempered.
That also. By the way, sir - I wouldn't stand too close to Mr. Shiny's grease valve.
If he has an emission it'll take the shine clean off your shoes.
Say  - nice sneakers!
Thanks.
Who broke the nurse's heart? Was it you?
Oh, no! Talk to a woman? I wouldn't know where to start...
My analyst says I'm socially inept.
Some analyst! Weren't you offended?
Not me. It's a comfort to have it made official.
You shouldn't take any notice of him. Everyone shines in their own way...
Yeah - I shine floors.
Nothing, really.
Yeah! Take care, now.
Take a look at this red nose...
Are you a policeman?.
No. This is a clown's nose, not a policeman's
Did I show you this nose, Sam?
Yeah, you did. It's a real humdinger... I think.
Would this tool be any use to you?
No, sir. Mr. Shiny has no user-serviceable parts.
Whatever that means...
Do you recognize this pass?
No, I don't. Should I?
No, but I wondered if you'd seen a stranger flashing it about...
No, sir. But if I had, Mr. Shiny would take care of him.
Would you like to shake my hand?
Not until I've washed if you don't mind, sir.
You can pick up all kinds of things in a hospital.
Like nurses, right?
No, sir - bugs and germs.
And fungal infections.
And a side order of machine oil.
What do you think of this, Sam?
Oh, boy!
What is it?
A priceless gemstone, found in a medieval castle in Ireland.
Get me into Marquet's ward and it's yours.
I don't wear jewelry.
If this gem was yours you'd be able to buy a hundred Mr. Shinys!
Don't be silly!
There's only one Mr. Shiny!
Don't you want this gem, Sam?
I'm quite happy without it, thanks.
Do you recognize this matchbook?
You should never, ever play with matches.
I know that, but...
People get hurt when they do.
Sure...
They end up in hospital like the burger-lady.
She was so burned-up they didn't know whether to use bandages or onions.
Do you recognise this powder?
Is that dandruff...?
No way!
It sure looks like dandruff.
It's plaster.
Ugh!
Yeah - I do.
Who is it?
That's what I'm asking you. Have you seen him before?
How should I know? You haven't told me who he is!
Take a look at the photo.
Yeah. Okay.
Now, have you seen him before?
You know what? If you start whistling I'll bust you in the teeth.
Have you seen any unsavory characters lurking about in the corridors?
You have a cold. What you need is vitamin C!
The nurse was stunningly beautiful. The guys on this ward sure were lucky to be in her care.
He sat like a statue of a sack of potatoes, but the cop's eyes were as watchful as a hawk's.
Now, I was no doctor, but this guy looked dead to me.
The guy was sick. His face was the same shade of gray as the pillow beneath his head.
I wondered whether I ought to call the nurse, maybe check him out for breathing...
This guy didn't look sick to me.
He didn't have spots, or stitches, and he certainly didn't have a fever...
Whoever decided to put this statue on a hospital ward was real sick.
Maybe it was there to ward away infection - or visitors.
I would have chosen something more cheerful than a woman holding a corpse.
The name on the chart was Boissy.
The poor guy's temperature had been up and down like a white-knuckle ride.
No wonder he looked so sick.
According to the chart, this guy was called Croquet.
The graph showed a steady decline in his pulse rate and an increase in his blood-pressure...
It kinda shook me to see this guy's life reduced to a few jagged lines...
The name on the chart was Sopmarsh.
His temperature was normal, with little fluctuation either way.
Oui, m'sieur?
Is this ward J-Two?
It is, but you are not supposed to be here!
We have strict rules about visiting hours.
Can't you make an exception? I've come all the way from California!
You must speak to the doctor...
I can't wait that long. What if he snuffs it?
You can't talk like that here! This is a hospital!
You will have to leave.
I told you to leave!

Docteur!
What is it now, nurse?
Number two again. He won't tell me what he wants.
He says he'll only talk to a man.
Do I have to? That guy's nuts!
Docteur, I'm surprised at you!
That's no way to talk about our clients!
Okay, okay - I'll see him, but I'm telling you - he's a hypochondriac.
Could you take a look at the client in bed number three, now?
His name is Eric Sopmarsh.
What's his problem?
He's delirious. He just now came out of theater.
He's recovering from major surgery.
I'll have him up and about before you can say `Lazarus, get out of your bed and walk'!
Good afternoon, docteur.
Oh, hi. Is this ward J-Two?
Yes, sir.
The patients are ready for your inspection, doctor
Uh - thank you, nurse.
Well, who's first?
M'sieur Croquet, in bed two.
What's his problem?
He's been complaining of loss of consciousness.
You'll need this, docteur...
She gave me a long, narrow metal box and a stunning smile...
Thanks.
Pardon me, nurse...
Oui, m'sieur?
Do you have a patient named Marquet on this ward?
Oui, m'sieur. He is in the private room at the end of the ward.
He has been placed in strict isolation.
Why is Marquet in quarantine?
v
All I know is that Marquet's room is strictly out of bounds.
You can tell me how my brother is, can't you?
Of course, m'sieur. What is his name?
Jacques Marquet.
Let me see...
He's `satisfactory'.
I was told he was dying!
Well, he is. But the doctor described his condition as `satisfactory'.
That's quite an improvement on yesterday.
Do you know who paid for Marquet's room?
No, of course I don't!
Preferential treatment like that must cost an arm and a leg...
That's not my concern, m'sieur.
Is it true that Marquet is suffering from anthrax?
Keep your voice down, m'sieur!
Who told you that?
The cop at the door.
v
Evacuate. That's it. No panic. Women and children first...
Has anyone ever told you how cute you are when you go to pieces?

My first step will be to burn the bodies.
Burn... the bodies?
It won't be easy, I know, but I can do it!
Just give me a chance, docteur! Let me burn the patients!
I don't think that would be a good idea, Nurse Grendel.
I'm sorry, docteur, but the other staff put me up to this.
It's because you're new, you see. Traditional hospital humor.
Hilarious. Then Marquet hasn't got anthrax?
No, sir.
Do you have any clowns on the ward?
Why, yes - we do. A professional clown.
I'll bet he lightens the place up!
Hardly. M'sieur Boissy has been in a coma for the last three months.
What's wrong with Boissy?
He was involved in a very nasty accident.
A silly stunt involving a unicycle.
His current condition is due to post-traumatic shock.
It's unlikely he'll ever perform as a clown again...
It's an ill wind that blows nobody any good.
Thank you, nurse.
You may come back at visiting time, m'sieur.
Thanks. When is that?
The second Tuesday of each month.
Au revoir, m'sieur!
Do you recognize this red nose?
Oh, dear. I don't think he'll be needing that again!
Who?
M'sieur Boissy, the comatose clown.

No, I don't.

No, I don't.
Does this tool mean anything to you?

Well...
Okay, forget it.
I didn't really want to use it on her anyway...
Do you recognise this tissue?

I've been carrying it around for days and I'm okay.
My pocket's getting a little soggy...
Hi! I'm Doctor Stobbart.
Hello doctor.
Hello, again!
The nurse told me you keep losing consciousness...
That's right! I've had the problem as long as I can remember.
It's a real out of body experience - like death, but not so conclusive.
I see. How long does it last?
Just a fraction of a second, then I recover.
I might not have been a doctor, but I was formulating a diagnosis all the same...
This guy was nuts.

Is it serious?
Of course it isn't serious! It's perfectly natural.
But just think: two seconds every minute - why, that's almost half an hour every day!
Two weeks out of every year spent in total darkness!
I don't have time to listen to this baloney.

You know how it is... life goes on.

Thanks, doc.

No, I don't.

Hello? Anybody home?

I guess they're right - I'd be stupid to tackle a bear single-handed.

I placed the cog and spindle back in the supporting frame.

There was no obvious way of removing the wheel from its housing.
The stone face of the demon grinned with a horribly life like expression.

The demon's face was complete, and the effect chilled me to the bone.

There was a simple reason: the demon didn't have any eyes.
I ran my fingers across the cold stone and probed the holes in the demon's eyes.

The cog turned freely, but nothing happened.
I tried turning the cogs but couldn't move them. I needed a mechanical advantage.
I pushed the handle into the demon's mouth - the cogs all meshed. I began to turn...
The cog slipped neatly into the eye socket.
With a rasp of metal on stone I eased the second eye into place.
With the clay pipe in his mouth he looked happy, homely, like somebody's grand-daddy.
Sometimes the most childish gestures can have a cathartic effect...
The transformation of the demon to a clown did just that for me.
